text:
Using Kelly and to what fraction vs other staking plans really depends on your approach and results I've found.
Generally Kelly is good for lower-odds and say, percent-of-bank is better for larger odds.
Proportional staking can be used but might sacrifice overall profit for reduced draw down.
All I can suggest is graphing the plans out on your results and see what you like the look of?
I'll find some examples I did a while back

elements.text:

text: So, this was a 1370 bet sample with average odds of $8, didn't seem to suit Kelly (graph is half Kelly, 10% edge assumed, was about 10% pot) Y axis scale is different.

elements.text: So, this was a 1370 bet sample with average odds of $8, didn't seem to suit Kelly (graph is half Kelly, 10% edge assumed, was about 10% pot) Y axis scale is different.

text: The issue here is that your edge estimate is wrong

elements.text: The issue here is that your edge estimate is wrong

text: Kelly is mathematically optimal. The hard part is estimating your true edge. Kelly also assumes you're not at market capacity. If you are, then kelly doesn't matter - you're limited by the size you can execute in the market. Other staking systems are fine, and a simple, conservative, fractional system will get you most of the same benefits (no risk of ruin being the primary one, but you also don't need to reclaculate your bet-size). The issue is that your capital growth isn't as rapid as with kelly, which sizes your bets appropriately. But again, you need to know what your edge is. One of the reasons people use fractional kelly is because estimating this is hard, and fractional kelly gives you more wiggle room to be wrong without negatively affecting your log growth rate. Just as a final point, If you bet > 2x true full kelly, your capital growth is actually negative and your bankroll will -> 0 over the long run (but it will never actually hit zero because you're wagering fractionally).

elements.text: Kelly is mathematically optimal. The hard part is estimating your true edge. Kelly also assumes you're not at market capacity. If you are, then kelly doesn't matter - you're limited by the size you can execute in the market. Other staking systems are fine, and a simple, conservative, fractional system will get you most of the same benefits (no risk of ruin being the primary one, but you also don't need to reclaculate your bet-size). The issue is that your capital growth isn't as rapid as with kelly, which sizes your bets appropriately. But again, you need to know what your edge is. One of the reasons people use fractional kelly is because estimating this is hard, and fractional kelly gives you more wiggle room to be wrong without negatively affecting your log growth rate. Just as a final point, If you bet > 2x true full kelly, your capital growth is actually negative and your bankroll will -> 0 over the long run (but it will never actually hit zero because you're wagering fractionally).

text:
More than likely! Always been my question with Kelly; what to input as the edge?
I would have thought pot would be an okay substitute but maybe not. I think in this particular dataset the profit was all in the higher odds runners (probably coincidence) and in that scenario Kelly didn’t work. 
Do you think that Kelly works in situations with high odds and high odds-ranges?

text: `The hard part is estimating your true edge` - yup this has been a primary concern for me in terms of using Kelly. I usually take quite a generous margin over my forecast, so consider a relatively large margin of error essentially.

text: And then with adverse selection at play...from a set of x large bets where you were very confident Vs the market, you might lose overall just because you got larger proportion of your bet filled when you were wrong and smaller fills when you were right...so not correctly estimating your true edge can lead to ruin :x

text: Determining edge is the holy grail! If you can do that, you know when the markets are wrong, and can consistently profit. It's not easy, no-one will give you an easy answer.

elements.text: Determining edge is the holy grail! If you can do that, you know when the markets are wrong, and can consistently profit. It's not easy, no-one will give you an easy answer.

text: Could Kelly be adapted to account for a stake/value trade off? What would that look like? For what I do estimating edge  is quite easy if you're content with an estimate of your edge at the point of execution, it's the matching that messes it up.

text: I doubt that Kelly has much practical application for most of us but it is interesting.

elements.text: I doubt that Kelly has much practical application for most of us but it is interesting.

text: By stake value trade off do you mean some model accounting for adverse selection based on available sizes?

elements.text: By stake value trade off do you mean some model accounting for adverse selection based on available sizes?

text: Wouldn't need to be available sizes but yeah it's adverse selection, the more you can match the worse your edge, so you'd start with some assumed edge X and then discount your edge at some rate according to your stake.

elements.text: Wouldn't need to be available sizes but yeah it's adverse selection, the more you can match the worse your edge, so you'd start with some assumed edge X and then discount your edge at some rate according to your stake.

text: Yeah it's possible to perform kelly calculations given existing positions, and you'd just adjust your edge as it changed and incorporate your already existing stakes

elements.text: Yeah it's possible to perform kelly calculations given existing positions, and you'd just adjust your edge as it changed and incorporate your already existing stakes

text: That's not what I mean. Say you estimate your edge at X then submit a bet with infinite stake, the amount that you get matched would cause you to revise your estimate of that bet's edge. So your Kelly optimal would be Y% of your bank, but if you could match that much then your edge estimate would be revised down and you'd have staked too much.

elements.text: That's not what I mean. Say you estimate your edge at X then submit a bet with infinite stake, the amount that you get matched would cause you to revise your estimate of that bet's edge. So your Kelly optimal would be Y% of your bank, but if you could match that much then your edge estimate would be revised down and you'd have staked too much.

text: Many of us will have worked out value/stake trade off curves from data, but can you adapt Kelly to serve this function?

elements.text: Many of us will have worked out value/stake trade off curves from data, but can you adapt Kelly to serve this function?

text: Obviously this isn't actually useful.

elements.text: Obviously this isn't actually useful.

text: Or let me put it another way: Say you submit a huge bet at a random price and have no estimate of EV. If none of it matches it must have been +EV, if it all matched -EV and something in-between gives you central values. So you can infer value from a size matched (to a degree). Can you factor that into Kelly such that your optimum stake takes account of that adverse selection?

elements.text: Or let me put it another way: Say you submit a huge bet at a random price and have no estimate of EV. If none of it matches it must have been +EV, if it all matched -EV and something in-between gives you central values. So you can infer value from a size matched (to a degree). Can you factor that into Kelly such that your optimum stake takes account of that adverse selection?

text: No, Kelly can't do that for you. The trade off curve you allude to is specific to the market you trade on, so there is no way for kelly to do it for you. You'd just have to perform your own estimate, and then adjust the inputs to kelly accordingly.

elements.text: No, Kelly can't do that for you. The trade off curve you allude to is specific to the market you trade on, so there is no way for kelly to do it for you. You'd just have to perform your own estimate, and then adjust the inputs to kelly accordingly.

text: Absolutely it could!

elements.text: Absolutely it could!

text: I know it can't - but could someone adapt/extend it?

elements.text: I know it can't - but could someone adapt/extend it?

text: I think that yes you can make adaptions - the fact you managed to get filled does indeed adjust your estimate of your edge, but you would just need to model your edge as as function of the size you're filled at.

elements.text: I think that yes you can make adaptions - the fact you managed to get filled does indeed adjust your estimate of your edge, but you would just need to model your edge as as function of the size you're filled at.

text: How you adapt it is by altering the inputs, though not sure if I'd even call that adapting it

elements.text: How you adapt it is by altering the inputs, though not sure if I'd even call that adapting it

text: Kelly boils down to maximizing your log-wealth growth, that function is pretty flexible and you can adapt it a lot, provided you can do the maths for the maximization.

elements.text: Kelly boils down to maximizing your log-wealth growth, that function is pretty flexible and you can adapt it a lot, provided you can do the maths for the maximization.

text:
That's an interesting question. If you have inferred a function that gives you an edge depending on stake size, then you could use Kelly to choose the size that gives you highest log wealth growth.
However if your bankroll is very large compared to the maximum possible +EV stake then the outcome should be "take everything with value" as your risk of ruin (or of reducing your bankroll to a tiny amount) is negligible.
So you could use it to balance risk vs +EV turnover, but if you have maxed out for market capacity already then Kelly obviously couldn't help you increase the market capacity.
In reality the problem would probably be more murky as you have a region where you don't know exactly at which size your bets start to leak value. I'm not sure how much Kelly could help you with that as it is ultimately about risk control and can't tell you where you reach the -EV region (it is always assumed that you know your edge).
I would love to have such a magic function for edge vs stake size for my strategies btw.

elements.text:

So you could use it to balance risk vs +EV turnover, but if you have maxed out for market capacity already then Kelly obviously couldn't help you increase the market capacity.
In reality the problem would probably be more murky as you have a region where you don't know exactly at which size your bets start to leak value. text: I still feel im barking up a wrong tree, randomly trying to figure fair horse prices based on wom, vwap, traded volumes, creating thresholds for say if 10% above my magic calculated fair price then Back etc..but I just seem to find no value. I cant believe any magic formula works

text: Am I likely to find value by randomly tweaking parameters?

elements.text: Am I likely to find value by randomly tweaking parameters?

text: No

elements.text: No

text: `randomly trying to figure fair prices` - like Michael said before, you need to have some logical basis as to why you think any of your inputs have some relationship with the fair price. Randomly trying these things is a tricky approach because you are probably shoving a lot of junk into your "magic formula", and therefore the derived "fair price" is also junk. Easy way to test - build two arrays: 1 containing all your fair prices, and 2 containing the outcomes (win=1, lose=0). Compute the roc_auc score using the scikit-learn package...this will essentially tell you if your fair prices are any better than random (auc>0.5), are good as random (auc=0.5), or worse than random (auc<0.5).

elements.text: `randomly trying to figure fair prices` - like Michael said before, you need to have some logical basis as to why you think any of your inputs have some relationship with the fair price. Randomly trying these things is a tricky approach because you are probably shoving a lot of junk into your "magic formula", and therefore the derived "fair price" is also junk. Easy way to test - build two arrays: 1 containing all your fair prices, and 2 containing the outcomes (win=1, lose=0). Compute the roc_auc score using the scikit-learn package...this will essentially tell you if your fair prices are any better than random (auc>0.5), are good as random (auc=0.5), or worse than random (auc<0.5).

text: @goatwish You haven't even started looking properly yet. That top 4 1s data was a waste of time and you've only got a couple of weeks api data. Have you got a methodology in place for looking at the effect of these randomly tweaked parameters? Do any exhibit a normalised distribution of the test pl, ie show any relevence? How many parameters are you trying to juggle. ie how many perms? You need to be much more thorough and methodical, even vwap should take you weeks to explore with all the variations of durations, combinations of durations, crossings, mvwaps etc etc.  I did say about 6 months ago that trying things at random won't work but you're still trying it!
